text.0: let these speak loudly forth let us speak out aloud to the loud speaking pressingstones address the speech.
text.1: when rich with soma juice stones of the mountain ye united swift to indra bring the sound of praise.
text.2: they speak out like a hundred like a thousand men they cry aloud to us with their greentinted mouths.
text.3: while pious stones they ply their task with piety and even before the hotar taste the offered food.
text.4: loudly they speak for they have found the savoury meath they make a humming sound over the meat prepared.
text.5: as they devour the branch of the redcoloured tree these the wellpastured bulls have uttered bellowings.
text.6: they cry aloud with strong exhilarating drink calling on indra now for they have found the meath.
text.7: bold with the sisters they have danced embraced by them making the earth reecho with their ringing sound.
text.8: the eagles have sent forth their cry aloft in heaven in the skys vault the dark impetuous ones have danced.
text.9: then downward to the nether stones fixt place they sink and splendid as the sun effuse their copious stream.
text.10: like strong ones drawing they have put forth all their strength the bulls harnessed together bear the chariotpoles.
text.11: when they have bellowed panting swallowing their food the sound of their loud snorting is like that of steeds.
text.12: to these who have ten workers and a tenfold girth to these who have ten yokestraps and ten binding thongs.
text.13: to these who bear ten reins the eternal sing ye praise to these who bear ten carpoles ten when they are yoked.
text.14: these stones with ten conductors rapid in their course with lovely revolution travel round and round.
text.15: they have been first to drink the flowing soma juice first to enjoy the milky fluid of the stalk.
text.16: these somaeaters kiss indras baycoloured steeds draining the stalk they sit upon the oxs hide.
text.17: indra when he hath drunk somameath drawn by them waxes in strength is famed is mighty as a bull.
text.18: strong is your stalk ye verily never shall be harmed ye have refreshment ye are ever satisfied.
text.19: fair are ye as it were through splendour of his wealth his in whose sacrifice o stones ye find delight.
text.20: bored deep but not pierced through with holes are ye o stones not loosened never weary and exempt from death.
text.21: eternal undiseased moving in sundry ways unthirsting full of fatness void of all desire.
text.22: your fathers verily stand firm from age to age they loving rest are not dissevered from their seat.
text.23: untouched by time neer lacking green plants and green trees they with their voice have caused the heavens and earth to hear.
text.24: this this the stones proclaim what time they are disjoined and when with ringing sounds they move and drink the balm.
text.25: like tillers of the ground when they are sowing seed they mix the soma nor devouring minish it.
text.26: they have raised high their voice for juice for sacrifice striking the mother earth as though they danced thereon.
text.27: so loose thou too his thought who hath effused the sap and let the stones which we are honouring be disjoined.
